awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the molecular mechanisms that enable several meters of DNA (the genome) to be packaged into a cell nucleus which has a diameter that is approximately 100,000 times smaller than this. This amazing degree of compaction of the DNA is achieved by repeatedly coiling of the DNA double helix around multiple spools, each of which is composed of protein (histone) cores. The DNA is thus formed into a "beads-on-a-string" array of DNA/histone particles called nucleosomes. The nucleosome arrays are then further folded into structures that include multiple loops where the DNA is physically constrained. Beyond a basic understanding of this structure, the architectural organization of the DNA-protein complex in the cell nucleus (known as chromatin), remains enigmatic. This research will use biochemical experiments and computational 3-dimensionsal modeling to describe the structural interactions of DNA in living cells and to predict how the structure impacts function. The project will promote education and training for graduate students and for undergraduates, including those from underrepresented groups and underserved areas of rural Pennsylvania who typically have little opportunity to participate in fundamental research. 

In most current textbooks, the higher-order structure of DNA is modeled based on zigzag or solenoidal folding of nucleosomes forming linear chromatin fibers. However, recent in vivo studies suggested a dynamic looping of flexible and disordered nucleosome arrays rather than linear fibers in most cell types. This project is centered on a hypothesis that different lengths and conformations of the linker DNA connecting nucleosome beads impose distinct topological states and orders of nucleosome packing that segregate the chromatin domains into either flexible nucleosome chains facilitating functional interactions between distant DNA elements or, alternatively, tightly packed nucleosomes that inhibit interactions between distant chromosomal sites. This hypothesis will be tested using a unique electron microscopy nucleosome interaction capture method, DNA topology assays, and computational modeling to determine patterns of nucleosome interactions and DNA topology of both circular arrays of precisely positioned nucleosomes and circular minichromosomes isolated from yeast cells. The results will provide a more detailed picture of chromatin organization as it is likely to exist in the cell, and this knowledge will serve as a framework for better understanding of how chromatin features regulate gene expression.

This award is co-funded by programs in Genetics Mechanism (Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences) and the Physics of Living Systems (Division of Physics).

Genes that encode the blueprints for any living cell are stored and passed from generation to generation in the form of DNA double helix molecules.  DNA of a typical human cell is densely packed in order to accommodate its almost 2-meter length into the much smaller (10 micrometer) nucleus of the cell. This packing is achieved through multiple levels of compaction in which the DNA is looped, folded, and supercoiled. DNA doesn't just do this by itself, but with the aid of special proteins that, together with DNA, form a complex called chromatin. The extent of DNA packing in chromatin may determine expression of particular genes in different cells as well as rates of DNA damage and repair.

At the very basic level of chromatin packing, the DNA is coiled by small proteins called histones into tiny (10 nanometer) repeated structures called nucleosomes which resemble "beads-on-a-string". Within each nucleosome "bead", the DNA double helix makes approximately 1.7 left superhelical turns around the nucleosome core containing 8 histone molecules. In the cell nucleus, nucleosome arrays form multiple loops to fold in large chromosomes; the density of such loops increases in dividing cells and decreases in differentiated cells that do not divide anymore. When the DNA ends of such "beads-on-a-string" are connected, it forms a small circular chain of nucleosomes called the minichromosome. The DNA in a circular minichromosome acquires a certain topology, a physical property inherent in any ring with edges such as a buckled belt or the Mobius strip. Surprisingly, despite the expectation of about 1.7 left superhelical turns per nucleosome, several previous studies have recorded only about 1.0 such turn per nucleosome.  This discrepancy, known as the superhelical paradox, was first noted by Francis Crick in 1975 who proposed that this paradox could arise from some unconventional DNA path in the minichromosome. Until now, this and other theoretical assumptions on the role of linker DNA in topology have not been tested. The aim of this project was to understand whether and how nucleosome positions and, especially, the length of the "strings" (called nucleosome linkers) between the "beads", influence DNA topology, minichromosome structure, and affect gene expression.

This project set out to re-examine this paradox using a set of engineered circular arrays with precisely positioned nucleosome beads separated by linker DNA strings of various lengths. These circular nucleosome arrays were analyzed by DNA topology assays, electron microscopy, and computational modeling. The results showed that the number of superhelical turns in a circular nucleosome chain depends on the length of the linker DNA and varies by as much as 0.5 superhelical turns per nucleosome. Furthermore, for the linker DNA containing several full turns plus one half-turn of the DNA double helix (the type of linker predominantly found in native chromatin), the results were consistent with the DNA topology observed in native circular minichromosomes.  Thus, this study reconciled the topological properties of nucleosome arrays with nucleosome core structure and provided a simple explanation for the DNA topology in native chromatin with variable DNA linker length without invoking any unconventional DNA path in the chromatin. Furthermore, by engineering nucleosome linkers with intrinsic bending either towards or away the nucleosome, it was possible to further modulate linker DNA geometry and nucleosome array compaction. This project also involved experiments with engineered circular minichromosomes propagating in baker' s yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae that showed that the DNA linker length may affect DNA stability and supercoiling in yeast cells. Collectively, the new findings suggest that distinct chromatin domains that are organized as topologically isolated loops, may acquire different linker DNA lengths, configurations, and supercoiling to confer different potentials for chromatin opening for gene expression and other DNA-dependent processes in living cells.  

The outcomes of this project were disseminated to scientific communities of molecular biologists, biophysicists, and computational scientists through research papers, review articles, presentations at scientific conferences and seminars. The results of this interdisciplinary study continue to be used for promoting education and training in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) in form of providing biochemical data, electron microscopy images, and chromatin models to be used in didactic materials and lectures for Penn State students as well as by outreach lectures in undergraduate colleges in south-central Pennsylvania. This project was also successful in providing research training, education, and opportunities for scientific communications and presentations for undergraduate students from the Summer Undergraduate Research program and other undergraduate training programs at Penn State Hershey. One former graduate student sponsored by this project became a faculty member at Gettysburg College and three research trainees entered PhD programs in leading research institutions. More information on this and other related studies on chromatin structure and function as well as training opportunities can be found online at   www.sergeigrigoryev.com
